prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Cold Molecular Gas in the Young Ring Galaxy Arp 147
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will use a single array pointing to image the distribution of the cold star forming ISM in the young ring galaxy Arp 147. While small and less evolved than the giant AM0644-741 and Cartwheel, it is gas rich and robustly forming stars. Unlike its two big brothers Arp 147's ring appears to be rich in molecular gas (f_mol = 0.5) using single dish 12CO(J=1-0) measurements. It may be an example of a ring galaxy whose ISM is not yet affected significantly by the long confinement in the starburst ring. High angular resolution (1.5" FWHM) CO observations with ALMA are required to map the distribution and kinematics of cold molecular gas and derive the ring's star formation law.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our correlator configuration was chosen to provide ample continuum channels for continuum subtraction (the alternative - 600 km/s bandwidth - seemed too small for comfort) and to allow flexibility in binning channels in dealing with regions of the ring with bright or faint line intensity.

Arp 147's ring has a radius of 9" and a thickness of 2-3" (see the Figures). We wish to confidently associate CO emission with the various HII complexes that are prominent in the H-alpha image, and (for example) determine the ring galaxy's star formation law. For this we need angular resolution (using Natural weighting for maximum sensitivity) comparable to their sizes and separation in the ring. 1.5" is our choice, though we will experiment with differnt weighting depending on the line S/N in the map making phase.

To estimate the expected 12CO(J=1-0) flux from the ring we distribute the 115 GHz single-dish velocity integrated line flux measured with the IRAM 30 m telescope (11.0 Jy km/s, 190 km/s width; Horellou et al. 1995) uniformly over the optical ring (solid-angle = 150 arcsec2). One synthesized beam (1.5 arcsec FWHM) corresponds to a solid angle of 2.55 arcsec2 and a velocity spread of 14 km/s assuming an ordered velocity field. We thus expect an averaged 115 GHz line flux density of 12 mJy/beam. Our experience in HI and CO observations of ring galaxies is that emission is never uniform on large scales, so we wish on-source integrations to attain 10-sigma detections on aveage. This will also ensure accurate CO kinematics and linewidth measurements. This can be accomplished in 0.55-hours (including calibration and overheads) according to the ALMA OT.
We expect to recover most if not all of the single-dish 12CO(J=1-0) line flux as the ring's largest diameter is comparable to the expected largest reliably imaged scale size. Arp 147's ring also occupies the inner-third of the 12 m antenna primary beam so mosaicing will not be required.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Cold Molecular Gas in the Evolved Ring Galaxy AM0644-741
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: AM0644-741 was the first ring galaxy to be sufficiently mapped in 12CO with a single-dish and the first to show evidence of a peculiar molecular ISM and star formation law. We attributed this to the ISM's long confinement in the robustly star forming ring where GMC/GMAs accumulate damage from expanding HII regions, SNe shocks, and sustained modest UV fields. We wish to use ALMA to extend these observations and study the distribution and kinematics of molecular gas with greatly improved angular resolution (~2" natural weighting) and sensitivity to probe the distribution and kinematics of cold molecular gas in the rings and interior.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our HI and 12CO observations show that our target AM0644-741 has a very large velocity width (740 km/s FWZI; Higdon et al. 2011). The total bandwidth/resolution we have chosen (1246 km/s & 1.3 km/s) in the 12CO(J=1-0) spectral window is adequate to include the line and provide flexibility in binning channels to deal with regions of the ring with bright or faint line intensity.

Our primary goal is to determine the distribution and kinematics of cold gas in and around the ring of AM0644-741, and in particular, to obtain a definitive CO-based star formation law. This requires that we be able to image molecular emission on scales comparable to the sizes and separations of HII complexes visible in (e.g.) the H-alpha image, which in the crowded areas where star formation is most intense, is ~2". Another consideration is the -74 degree declination of this source. which would seem to preclude the CW36-1 array as the shadowing fraction exceeds 20% ( this drops to <10% in the CW36-2 configuration). A 2" Natural weighted angular resolution will allow us to meet our science goals, recover adequate large scale emission, and make observing more efficient.

To estimate the expected 12CO(J=1-0) line flux per 2.0" synthesized beam (Natural weighted) we took the 115 GHz line flux and width measured by the SEST (44" FWHM; Higdon et al. 2011) and distributed it along the ring's solid angle within a given beam pointing (220 or 440 arcsec2, depending on whether or not there were two ring segments). One synthesized beam corresponds to a solid angle of 4.5 arcsec2 and a typical velocity drop (assuming a regular velocity field) of 10 km/s. Doing this for each pointing, we find expected 12CO(J=1-0) flux densities from 20-80 mJy/beam. We request time to reach a 10-sigma detection at the fainter positions (i.e., rms of 2 mJy/beam). Not only will this ensure accurate CO kinematics, it will help us pull CO flux out of the noise in the parts of the ring we did not detect with the SEST but where massive star formation is evident in H-alpha maps.
For an 11-point mosaic an rms of 2 mJy/beam with 10 km/s resolution will require 2.61-hours including calibration and overheads.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Dense Gas in the Young Ring Galaxy Arp 147
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will use a single array pointing to image the distribution of dense (n>10^4 cm-3) star forming ISM in the young ring galaxy Arp 147 using the J=1-0 HCN and HCO+ lines. While small and less evolved than the giant AM0644-741 and Cartwheel, it is gas rich and robustly forming stars. Unlike its two big brothers Arp 147's ring appears to be rich in molecular gas (f_mol = 0.5) using single dish 12CO(J=1-0) measurements. It may be an example of a ring galaxy whose ISM is not yet affected significantly by the long confinement in the starburst ring. We will derive the dense gas star formation law for comparison with the analog derived using 12CO(J=1-0) emission. Only ALMA can provide the required angular resolution and sensitivity for this experiment.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our correlator configuration was chosen to provide ample channels for continuum subtraction and to allow for flexibility in binning channels to deal with regions of the ring with faint line strength.

Arp 147's ring has a radius of 9" and a thickness of 2-3" (see the Figures). We wish to confidently associate HCN and HCO+ emission with the luminous HII complexes visible in the H-alpha image to (for example) derive the dense gas star formation law. For this we require Natural weighted angular resolutions similar to their sizes and separations in the ring. At the same time we must consider the time required to detect these faint lines. We have settled on a 1.7" FWHM (Natural weighted) synthesized beam, though we will experiment with different weighting and velocity resolution depending on the line S/N in the map making stage.
The diameter of Arp 147's ring is essentially the same as the largest recoverable angular scale.

Our desired angular resolution of 1.7" FWHM at 89 GHz (Natural weighting) is well matched to the dimensions of Arp 147's starburst ring which will enhance our ability to detect line emission. 1.7" is moreover comparable to the angular resolution of our ancillary data, particularly the H-alpha image which shows numerous HII complexes spaced around the ring ("beads-on-a-string").
To estimate the expected HCN(J=1-0) line flux from the ring we first assume that I_HCH/I_CO=0.1, which is the typical value for starburst galaxies (e.g., Imanishi et al. 2007). In this case the expected total HCN line flux from the ring become 1.10 Jy km/s. A single 1.7" FWHM synthesized beam then represents a solid angle of 3.3 arcsec2 and a velocity drop of 19 km/s (assuming a regular velocity field). Spread evenly oer the 150 arcsec2 ring we expect an average HCN line flux density of 1.3 mJy/Beam. A 5-sigma detection will require an rms of 0.26 mJy. For a velocity resolution of 40 km/s (this is OK since we will be using the brighter 12CO(J=1-0) data for the ring kinematics) this sensitivity can be reached in 2.42-hours (including calibration and overheads) according to the Cycle-3 ALMA OT.
We expect HCO+/HCN ~ 1.0 so the above considerations hold for this line as well.
Since the 18" diameter ring is within the inner-third of the 12 m primary beam at 89 GHz we do not have to mosaic. We also expect to recover most (if not all) of the galaxy's emission as the largest reliably imaged structure is somewhat larger than the ring at this frequency.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Dense Gas in the Evolved Ring Galaxy AM0644-741
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will mosaic AM0644-741's starburst ring in 6-array pointings to image the distribution of the dense (n>10^4 cm-3) molecular ISM using the J=1-0 HCN and HCO+ transitions. AM0644-741's CO-based star formation law is peculiar. We will derive the analogous HCN star formation law has been found to be linear in galaxies as diverse as ordinary spirals and ULIRGs.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our HI and 12CO observations show that AM0644-741 has a very large velocity width (740 km/s FWZI; Higdon et al. 2011). One small (22") region of the ring shows a FWZI of 640 km/s in both 12CO lines. The total bandwidth/resolution we have chosen (1621 km/s and 3.4 km/s) in the HCN/CHO+ spectral window is adequate to include the line and provide flexibility in binning channels to bring out faint line emission.

Our primary goal is to determine the distribution of dense (n>10^4 cm-3) gas traced by the J=1-0 HCN and HCN+ lines relative to the luminous star forming complexes around AM0644-741's ring(s) to derive an HCN-based star formation law for comparison with those of other galaxies (normal to ULIRGs) as well as the analogous CO-based law. We need an angualar resolution on par with the sizes and spacings of HII complexes visible in our ancillary H-alpha, UV, and infrared data, which is ~2". Our choice of angular resolution for these 89 GHz observations is 2.6" FWHM (Natural weighting). This choice is further motivated by our desire to avoid shadowing due to the -74 degree declination of AM0644-741, which can affect >20% of our data in the smallest C36-1 array configuration. The 2.6" Natural weighted angular resolution will allow us to meet our science goals, recover adequate large scale emission, and make observing more efficient.

To estimate the expected HCN(J=1-0) flux density within a 2.6" (Natural weighted) synthesized beam we uniformly spread the 12CO(J=1-0) line flux measured with SEST (44"; Higdon et al. 2011) over the ring's solid angle within the beam (220 or 440 arcsec2 depending on the number of ring segments) for each of the telescope pointings. We then assume I_HCN/I_CO(1-0) = 0.1 (as is observed in other starburst galaxies). One synthesized beam represents a solid angle of 7.7 arcsec2 and a velocity drop of 15 km/s assuming an ordered velocity field. Doing this for each pointing around the ring we calculate expected HCN line flux densities from 2.5 to 12 mJy/Beam. We wish integrations sufficient to reach an rms of 0.5 mJy to enable 5-sigma detections where emission is faintest. We are mosaicing AM0644-741's outer ring using 6-array pointings. This is justified since no 12CO emission was detected by SEST from the nucleus or disk, and because all the massive star formation (and thus dense gas) is found in the outer ring.
According to the Cycle-3 ALMA OT we can reach the desired sensivitity in our 6-point mosaic in 4.9-hours with 40 km/s velocity resolution, including time for calibfation and overheads. We will derive kinematic and line width information using the much more luminous 12CO(J=1-0) observations. Observations show HCO+/HCN ~ 1 in starburst galaxies, so the above considerations for HCN also hold for HCO+.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The ``snow plowing'' of >90% of a ring galaxy's ISM into an expanding ring triggers a starburst that persists for >100 Myrs, and subjects the ISM to prolonged damage from the embedded OB stars. This appears to lead to a peculiar ISM state manifested by low molecular fractions, low-density photodissociated HI, and non-SK star formation laws in which H2 and SFR/area appear uncorrelated. To examine the role played by ring age on the ISM we will use ALMA to image 12CO(J=1-0), HCN(J=1-0) and HCO+(J=1-0) emission from the young ring galaxy Arp 147. Together with our UV<-->radio data we will compare its H2 distribution, total and dense H2 fractions, and SFE with local conditions in the ring. We will also see if its CO-based star formation law is peculiar. HCN and HCO+ line emission will enable the derivation of the dense gas star formation law, which holds for ordinary spirals to ULIRGs. We also with to observe the large and evolved ring galaxy AM0644-741, previously observed with the SEST, to refine its CO-based star formatin law, measure its dense gas star formation law, and examine the nature of its ``coiled-rope'' starburst ring from its detailed gas distribution and kinematics.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: The Over-Cooked ISM in the Cartwheel Ring Galaxy (2012.1.00720.S)
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: The Over-Cooked ISM in the Cartwheel Ring Galaxy (2012.1.00720.S) Dense Molecular Gas in the Young Ring Galaxy Arp 147 (2013.1.00895.S)
